SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: Why are lines 14 through 18 important to the article?

A.Choice: They explain how old maps were inaccurate.

B.Choice: They emphasize the limited knowledge of geography at the time.

C.Choice: They emphasize Great Britain's knowledge of sea exploration.

D.Choice: They explain Great Britain's choice for using James Cook to explore unknown lands.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 25 and 26.
:box:Cook was ambitious and quickly learned that his ability to read set him apart from other sailors, even ones much older than he was.
Which evidence from the article best supports the author's claim in these lines?

A.Choice: “While the merchant ships he worked on carried cargo from port to port, James Cook assumed more and more responsibility as a navigator and learned the ways of the sea.” (lines 30 through 32)

B.Choice: “After ten years on the collier, Cook decided to join the Royal Navy.” (line 34)

C.Choice: “Its officers were recognized not only as outstanding sailors but also as 'gentlemen.'” (lines 35 and 36)

D.Choice: “During the trip, he also explored New Zealand and the east coast of Australia, which had never been visited by a European.” (lines 53 and 54)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the article, why were cartographers so valued during Cook's lifetime?

A.Choice: They provided the information ships required to stay on course while at sea.

B.Choice: They were responsible for informing the public of the names of unfamiliar regions.

C.Choice: They prevented sailors from visiting exotic lands with unknown dangers.

D.Choice: They were assigned the duty of teaching other sailors to read and draw maps.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: What idea about Cook is demonstrated by lines 16 through 53?

A.Choice: his impressive experience with the collier Endeavour

B.Choice: the necessity of sending him to North America

C.Choice: the praise he deserved for expanding Great Britain's territory

D.Choice: his effectiveness in drawing charts

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: What connection does the article make between astronomy and navigation?

A.Choice: Explorers traveled the seas to try to discover new planets and stars.

B.Choice: Explorers used maps to determine the positions of planets and stars.

C.Choice: Traveling on the sea was difficult without a reference to the position of the sun and stars.

D.Choice: Traveling on the sea required a constant view of the sun and stars.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How do lines 51 through 58 develop a central idea of the article?

A.Choice: by naming previously unknown lands

B.Choice: by emphasizing Cook's value to the navy

C.Choice: by describing Cook's contributions to exploration

D.Choice: by explaining improvements in the study of geography

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the author organize the ideas in the article?

A.Choice: by explaining how James Cook encouraged Great Britain to seek out new lands

B.Choice: by showing how the lack of reliable maps caused dangers in early ocean expeditions

C.Choice: by relating events sequentially to elaborate on James Cook's accomplishments

D.Choice: by describing ship instruments to show the development of sea navigation

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: The author's purpose in lines 4 through 7 is to

A.Choice: give examples of the variety of sports available

B.Choice: emphasize the benefits of participating in sports

C.Choice: provide reasons for letting her family play sports

D.Choice: show a personal connection to the topic of sports

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: According to the article, why have injuries to veterans influenced studies of athletes with concussions?

A.Choice: Thousands of veterans have been diagnosed with traumatic brain injuries.

B.Choice: Repeated head injuries are potentially damaging to the brain or spinal cord.

C.Choice: Repeated head injuries sustained in sports and combat have similar outcomes.

D.Choice: Public awareness of the symptoms and seriousness of head injuries has been growing.

SubTopics: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 22 and 23.
:box:No longer can a soccer player or cyclist just “walk off” a bump to the head.
What does the phrase “walk off” suggest?

A.Choice: The injury is made worse by moving around.

B.Choice: The person needs to leave the playing area.

C.Choice: The person is not seriously injured.

D.Choice: The injury does not affect the legs.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Lines 26 through 32 support the central idea that

A.Choice: progress is being made to make sports safer for kids

B.Choice: resistance to changes in youth sports is being overcome

C.Choice: children count on parents and coaches to keep them safe

D.Choice: a lack of training in treating brain injuries has inspired legislation

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read these sentences from lines 44 through 47.

:box:Sports-related brain injuries are also receiving more public attention because of the willingness of professional athletes to speak out. For example, more than 2,000 retired NFL℠ players filed a lawsuit against football helmet maker Riddell® and the NFL℠ for hiding information about dangers of concussions and the consequences of hits to the head.
Which inference do these sentences best support?

A.Choice: Older helmets do not protect athletes from head injuries.

B.Choice: The problem of head injuries is not confined to student athletes.

C.Choice: Professional athletes are reluctant to report head injuries during their careers.

D.Choice: Legal action is an effective way to discover information about the dangers of concussions.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 50 through 52.
:box:By taking what we already know, we can create opportunities for our children to participate in sports while keeping them healthy and safe.
Which lines best support the author's claim in this sentence?

A.Choice: “We are already learning a lot about traumatic brain injuries from our returning Afghanistan and Iraq veterans. An estimated 40,000 men and women veterans have been diagnosed with traumatic brain injuries from multiple concussions in combat.” (lines 15 through 17)

B.Choice: “According to the American Association of Neurological Surgeons (AANS), roughly 446,788 sports-related head injuries were treated at U.S. emergency rooms in 2009.” (lines 20 and 21)

C.Choice: “Recently, the largest youth football league, Pop Warner, announced it will limit the amount of contact and collisions in practice to protect its 285,000 football players (ages 5-15) from potential repetitive brain trauma. This move responded to a recent study of second-grade football players that showed the average player suffers more than 100 head impacts during 5 games and 10 practices.” (lines 3 through 37)

D.Choice: “Sports-related brain injuries are also receiving more public attention because of the willingness of professional athletes to speak out. For example, more than 2,000 retired NFL℠ players filed a lawsuit against football helmet maker Riddell® and the NFL℠ for hiding information about dangers of concussions and the consequences of hits to the head.” (lines 44 through 48)

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which claim can be supported by evidence from the article?

A.Choice: Participating in youth sports can expose children to risks.

B.Choice: Limiting physical contact during practice keeps players safer during games.

C.Choice: The age that a child begins playing football is related to the incidence of head injuries.

D.Choice: Poorly made sports equipment accounts for increases in head injuries among professional athletes.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read lines 10 and 11.
:box:He could sit and watch the tube and munch on some junk, or he could go to bed because it was getting late, or ...
These lines suggest that Terry

A.Choice: prefers to relax in the evening

B.Choice: disapproves of snacking in front of the television

C.Choice: wants to do something different from his usual activities

D.Choice: wastes time deciding whether to watch television or sleep

SubTopics: Analyze how a drama’s or poem’s form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning.
Content: How do lines 16 through 23 mostly contribute to the story?

A.Choice: by describing the types of tools made for fixing cars

B.Choice: by revealing details about the previous owner of the tools

C.Choice: by suggesting that Terry has had previous experience fixing cars

D.Choice: by showing that Terry has all the necessary tools for the work he plans to do

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on lines 24 through 29, readers can conclude that Terry

A.Choice: rarely works in the garage

B.Choice: feels proud of his possessions

C.Choice: is worried about losing his tools

D.Choice: is still becoming familiar with his tools

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: What is the main significance of the cat clock in the story?

A.Choice: Details about the clock help the reader to better understand the characters.

B.Choice: Descriptions of the clock provide clues about upcoming conflicts.

C.Choice: Descriptions of the clock help the reader to understand the theme.

D.Choice: Details about the clock add suspense to the story.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: In lines 5 through 59, what does “Time seemed to stop” suggest about Terry?

A.Choice: Terry works very quickly.

B.Choice: Terry is absorbed in his task.

C.Choice: Terry forgets to eat his dinner.

D.Choice: Terry is ignoring the cat clock.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Which lines best reveal the change in Terry's attitude toward the task he has chosen?

A.Choice: “'Let's see what we've got ...,' Terry said under his breath and started taking the boxes off, setting them around the garage on the floor, looking in each one as he did so.” (lines 39 and 40)

B.Choice: “All of that he knew, could understand, but there were numbered bags and boxes with just bolts and parts, and many of them made no sense to him, and he despaired of ever understanding it all when in the bottom of one of the boxes he found the instructions.” (lines 43 through 46)

C.Choice: “'A monkey could do this,' he said, sitting on the frame, going page by page. 'You don't have to know anything about cars at all. It's beautiful ...'” (lines 50 and 51)

D.Choice: “Not only were the instructions complete but they explained what was in each numbered box or bag what each set of bolts was for and he set about organizing all of them to get ready for starting work on the car.” (lines 52 through 54)

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: How does the setting affect the plot of the story?

A.Choice: The pile of boxes and car parts motivate him to clean up the garage.

B.Choice: The instructions and set of tools inspire Terry to work on the car.

C.Choice: The car parts and tools in the garage bring up memories Terry has long forgotten.

D.Choice: The time of night gives Terry time to do something interesting.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Read these sentences from lines 13 through 16.

:box:A cramped public-school test kitchen might seem an unlikely outpost for a food revolution. But Collazo and scores of others across the country-celebrity chefs and lunch ladies, district superintendents and politicians-say they're determined to improve what kids eat in school.
Which central idea is supported by these sentences?

A.Choice: It is not easy to make changes in school lunch programs.

B.Choice: Public schools have become test kitchens for improving the American diet.

C.Choice: Many people have been seeking to improve the nutritional value of school lunches.

D.Choice: Educating students about nutrition can improve their health for the rest of their lives.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 16 through 18.
:box:Most school cafeterias are staffed by poorly trained, badly equipped workers who churn out 4.8 billion hot lunches a year.
What does the phrase “churn out” suggest about the school lunches?

A.Choice: They are mass-produced without careful planning.

B.Choice: They are easily prepared using modern kitchens.

C.Choice: They are economically made and include nutritious ingredients.

D.Choice: They are thoughtfully created and include wide-ranging menus.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 24 and 25.
:box:As rates of childhood obesity and diabetes skyrocket, public-health officials say schools need to change the way kids eat.
Why should this information be included in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: It predicts the consequences of current eating habits for students.

B.Choice: It emphasizes the importance of healthy meal options for students.

C.Choice: It suggests that schools are responsible for diseases related to eating.

D.Choice: It highlights the role school administrators have in teaching healthy habits.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Based on lines 24 through 30 of the article, what is an obstacle to improving nutrition outside of school?

A.Choice: Families do not make time to cook meals at home.

B.Choice: Kids enjoy watching ads for fast food.

C.Choice: Health officials hinder meal planning by parents.

D.Choice: Kids do not know how to grow fresh produce.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How do lines 36 through 16 mostly contribute to the development of ideas in the article?

A.Choice: They show how restaurateurs can get involved to improve school lunches.

B.Choice: They show how easily students accepted healthy changes to school food.

C.Choice: They use the Santa Fe school district as an example of how change happens gradually.

D.Choice: They explain why a Santa Fe school district did not serve fruits and vegetables.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on lines 43 through 46, which statement about school kitchens is most likely true?

A.Choice: They do not have professional cooks.

B.Choice: They have too little time to prepare healthy foods.

C.Choice: They are not equipped to serve fresh foods.

D.Choice: They contain older equipment that should be replaced.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to lines 47 through 56, why is cost a factor in changing school food?

A.Choice: Schools receive income from the sale of popular but unhealthy vending machine snacks.

B.Choice: Schools across the country have to buy new vending machines to sell healthy snacks.

C.Choice: Students have less money to buy healthy snacks from vending machines.

D.Choice: New vending machines stock healthy but expensive snacks.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: Why is Captain Brooks' and his crew's knowledge of the island of Juan Fernandez important in “[Excerpt from] Shipwrecked Sailor”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Shipwrecked Sailor,” how does the attitude of the crew members change throughout the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: The author learns a lesson about culture from his grandmother. How does the author learn this lesson? How does the author show that this lesson has remained with him into his adult life? Use details from the passage to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• identify the lesson about culture that the grandmother teaches the author
• explain how the author learns this lesson
• explain how the author shows this lesson has remained with him into his adult life
• use details from the passage to support your response

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium's portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: How does the photograph aid the reader's understanding of the article? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: Why have experts from different fields of study been involved in this research? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Buddha Boy,” what theme do lines 35 through 58 develop? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how a drama’s or poem’s form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Buddha Boy,” why are lines 81 through 84 important to the plot of the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] One + One = Blue,” what effect does the difference in Basil's point of view and Tenzie's point of view regarding Basil's family have on the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Buddha Boy” and ”[Excerpt from] One + One = Blue,” both Justin and Basil take chances that they learn from. What chances do they each take? What do they learn about themselves through the conversations and events in each story? Use details from both stories to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain what chances Justin and Basil each take
• explain what they learn about themselves through the conversations and events in each story
• use details from both stories to support your response
